repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Rural Water Supply
            and Sanitation Pilot Project for Madagascar was
            satisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was substantial, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both satisfactory.
            Lessons learned from the project: Professional NGOs can be
            instrumental to support rural communities to formulate the
            project, for keeping capital cost low and for providing
            assistance to communities after facilities have been built
            improving sustainability. Rural communities can contribute
            significantly towards the capital cost of the project,
            mostly in kind, as well as 100 percent of operation and
            maintenance cash costs. Economies of scale can be achieved
            by grouping construction activities to be carried out in
            small rural communities under large multi-year umbrella
            contracts. It is necessary to include sanitation and
            improved hygiene behavior in the design of a rural water
            supply and sanitation project design from the very
            beginning, as it appears very difficult to catch up during
            project implementation. Hand washing with soap should be
            part of any rural water supply and sanitation national
            strategy as it is a key element for reducing the risk of
            contracting intestinal diseases and thus improving health
            outcomes of the project. Regular water quality testing and
            measures to improve and maintain drinking quality water,
            especially bacteriological standards, are necessary and must
            be closely monitored.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Pilot Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA) for
            the Rural Water Supply and Sanitation Pilot Project, reviews
            Madagascar's legal, administrative, and sectoral
            framework, to then assess potential, adverse environmental
            impacts which may result from implementation of the project.
            Based on a geological survey, it assesses the hydrological
            potential for the development of water supply
            infrastructure, i.e., both rainfall parameters, as well as
            surface water, and groundwater resources, and examines as
            well the climatic conditions, and how it affects vegetation.
            Environmental protection will be enhanced within an
            institutional framework, reinforced by Committees at the
            village levels, to ensure mitigation, through the
            establishment of watershed management at the micro level
            which would enhance groundwater recharge, minimize soil
            erosion, and promote re-vegetation, particularly in the
            drier areas. An appropriate site selection should minimize
            hydraulic interference between existing, and new dug/bore
            well sources, while weirs, and barrages will be built to
            ensure river water flows, and flush off pollutants.

repnme.cdata!:
MADAGASCAR - Rural Water Supply and
            Sanitation Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the Rural Water
            Supply and Sanitation Pilot Project is to ensure an improved
            capacity of the Government, communities, and private sector
            to expand a sustainable and cost-effective coverage in water
            supply and sanitation. The project components are: 1) policy
            and legal framework for the sector, assisting in: i)
            reformulation of the water and sanitation sector policy and
            implementation arrangements; ii) preparation of a water law;
            and iii) promoting enforcement of water policy and
            regulations; 2) sector reorganization and capacity building
            to ensure that sector organization is relevant to the policy
            framework; and 3) community based water and sanitation
            services (pilot), to be implemented in two parts -part A:
            assisting the Government in preparing a community needs
            assessment, education and support studies in order to reach
            a better knowledge of sector; and part B: assistance in
            water and sanitation services extension, including
            boreholes, gravity systems and civil works to support the
            sector capacity building efforts. The project will also
            finance pilot water and sanitation systems in targeted rural areas.
